tags: you come to ryme city & you gotta haul yr six gigantic battle scarred pokemon around outside their balls everywhere you go ???
the cops are gonna be FOLLOWING you
summary: The idea of Pokemon battles being illegal in Ryme City is,,, so funny when you think about it in the context of a world where...
body:
The idea of Pokemon battles being illegal in Ryme City is,,, so funny when you think about it in the context of a world where powerful Pokemon trainers are essentially celebrities.

Like… imagine you lived in a city where Britney Spears is technically a fugitive.

summary: Pokemon: Detective Pikachu - Movie Review (Spoiler Free)
title: Pokemon: Detective Pikachu - Movie Review (Spoiler Free)
body:
Before I start this, I want to say that it’s spoiler free which might make it a little vague. I’ll start with the downsides so that I can leave this off on a positive note since I did like the movie. Okay, here we go!

The characters weren’t fleshed out nearly enough. In fact, I don’t even remember their names. Not one name has stuck around in my head except those of Pokemon. They did try to give the main character a backstory but it fell flat and was very generic for a detective movie. You could probably guess it by what I just said. There is nothing original in it and, for me, it failed to evoke the feelings it was supposed to.

Pikachu is, in fact, the character that is most fleshed out and is the heart and soul of the movie which is awesome since that’s why you’re watching the movie. But it wouldn’t have hurt to give the other characters a little more opportunities to shine and reveal what is special and unique about them. As it was, Pikachu is the star of the movie and everyone else is just a supporting shadow in the background.

The story wasn’t bad in itself but the execution was a little choppy for my taste. It was like “They’re here, doing something, and now they’re in this other place, doing another thing, and then they go to a third place…” and so on. You get the idea. You can still see the plotlines that hold all of that together but everything feels kind of disjointed and once or twice it was a little too jarring for me.

The thing that bothers me most is that they tried to shoehorn a subplot in there by telling us it was there when it actually wasn’t. They just state it as a fact but you haven’t seen it develop properly in order for it to be believable. It was shoved in there because we couldn’t possibly survive without it while it would’ve probably been a lot better than what they did to make it happen. There just wasn’t a proper set up in order to draw the conclusion that the movie did.

Now that I’ve complained about what bothered me, it’s time to see what I loved in the movie. There are three things that I liked and enjoyed and as it seems they were enough to make me overlook the stuff I listed above and enjoy the movie.

First, the bond that was formed along the way between Pikachu and the main character. The way it was done had me genuinely invested in it and I was rooting for this duo long before the end of the movie (probably way before the middle too). It was heartwarming and enjoyable to watch this relationship progress and if that wasn’t enough, the ending made it even better although it put things in a much different perspective.

Speaking of which, the movie has at least three major twists, and they were all done so well. When the truth is revealed, the pieces immediately click and you have no trouble remembering the foreshadowing. In fact, you go “Holy shit! I should’ve seen it coming!” and “I knew something felt off there.” Also, the villain had an interesting plan that, I have to admit, had its appeal.

And last but not least, POKEMON! Let’s be honest, that’s why we all went to watch the movie, I had no idea what it was about, I hadn’t watched the trailer and I still went to see this movie because it’s a movie about pokemon. How can you skip that? You shouldn’t! Pokemon were absolutely awesome and totally adorable in this movie. It had an abundance of different pokemon and all of them got to show some of their powers which was totally awesome because that was the whole appeal of the movie, it’s what sold it to the public and it did that well. All pokemon were memorable to a point that they outshined the human characters and totally stole the movie, which in this case is a good thing.

I did like the movie. The human characters and the story were lacking a bit, but it completely delivered on the pokemon front and that was enough to make it worthwhile. I didn’t go to the theater expecting a great story and unforgettable characters. I expected to watch pokemon for an hour and a half and that’s exactly what I got so I left the theater satisfied.

I'm Zai, A traditional artist of comics and a student of fine arts. I'm also known as Nell-tu-lover on deviantART, and this is currently my main blog.
Please enjoy your time here! :D

tags: just spare me the spoilers of detective pikachu
body:
A little notice.

I would like to continue avoiding spoilers for Detective Pikachu’s movie. As in, I still have not watched it, despite the recommendations and the opinions of those who watched it. ^^;

I may have to wait for the digital/DVD version to buy, or find an opportunity to watch it in cinema. I’m not sure if I’d go for otherwise choices; I’d want to enjoy the movie at its best quality, if possible.

Also, I’ve heard some good things about it. (I so wanna see Mewtwo there! xD)

I already know that this movie is a treat for Mewtwo fans, so I’ll be patient and wait a little while longer. :D

That’s all. Thanks for reading! ^^

it’s so good, and so much fun!
I’m sad it’s over, but I have the next game to look forward to~

blog.name: nerdsassemble
blog.title: Nerds Assemble
blog.description: Nerds Assemble is a  UK based podcast that deals with films, TV shows, videogames, comics/TPBs, graphic novels, anime, manga and much, much more.

title: Nerds Assemble 244 - Things we saw
body:
This episode: We have a general catch up on everything we’ve been doing recently.

Join the Emily, Paul and Paul as they chat about Lucifer season 4, Fear the Walking Dead season 3, Detective Pikachu, Tucca and Bertie, Final Fantasy X, Mortal Kombat 11, John Wick 2, Spider-Man Into the Spiderverse, Venom, Moneyland and The Rookie.

So, are you sitting comfortably?

Click here to listen in your browser (right-click and ‘Save As’ to download).

Find the podcast on Stitcher here.

Find the podcast on iTunes here.

RSS here.

Any feedback or questions? Let us know via the comments below or on Facebook or Twitter.

blog.name: claustre

blog.description:
I draw whatever takes my fancy
Will take commissions if asked

summary: Did a collab with the wonderful @azurenika drawing our bulba-sonas. Drawing a bulbasaur is honestly the most relaxing thing....
caption: Did a collab with the wonderful @azurenika drawing our bulba-sonas. Drawing a bulbasaur is honestly the most relaxing thing. Look at these cute beans!

blog.name: loracarol
blog.title: If there is magic on the planet, it is contained in the water.

summary: maybe it’s just me but tbh? I’m not super comfortable dismissing Tim/Lucy as just ‘comphet’ given how rare black men/white women...
body:
maybe it’s just me but tbh? I’m not super comfortable dismissing Tim/Lucy as just ‘comphet’ given how rare black men/white women relationships are in media - like when was the last time you saw one that was just treated like…. normal? especially in kids’ media? And their relationship ends happy? [some spoilers]

like, I’m not trying to be sarcastic, I genuinely can’t think of the last time I saw that - though I’m not super into kids’ media nowadays, so it’s 100% possible I’m missing something - but like, off the top of my head the only ones I can think of are Holes (Sam is murdered), Othello (Othello is dehumanized and murders his wife before killing himself, not for kids), Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner (not for kids, drama), and Get Out! (horror, not for kids) 

but Tim? Tim is the hero.

and in Detective Pikachu, it’s just treated like a normal young adult relationship. they find each other attractive (what Lucy’s face as he walks away from her office), they become friends, they trust each other (no arguing over whether or not she should go with him to the bad guy’s office, she trusts him to take care of it \ he trusts her to find a way to get the news out) he’s discombobulated when the ditto turns into her, and then afterwards they talk about meeting up later. there’s no Big Damn Kiss from two people who’ve just met, just two young adults who are mutually attracted to each other making plans to meet up later. also, it’s a black man and a white woman - and Tim is never portrayed as predatory. idk, maybe I’m off base, but I was surprised bc I genuinely can’t remember the last time I saw that in kids’ media - but again, I’m older so I could be Out Of Touch With The Young Folk. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
